title: Chi Chi Dango Recipe
description: Chi chi dango, a mochiko dessert confection, is a soft, chewy, sticky Japanese treat made with glutinous rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Asian Japanese Chi Chi Dango 4.7 (102) 87 Reviews 26 Photos Chi chi dango, a mochiko dessert confection, is a soft, chewy Japanese treat that is very similar in taste to mochi. It's traditionally served at Girl's Day or Boy's Day celebrations. It makes a great snack for picnics or parties. This recipe is easy to make, but don't double the directions — follow them exactly as written. Submitted by dewny dewny Updated on November 25, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 26 26 26 26 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 1 hr Additional Time: 30 mins Total Time: 1 hr 45 mins Servings: 36 Yield: 36 squares Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 36 servings cooking spray 1 pound mochiko (glutinous rice flour) 2 ½ cups white sugar 1 teaspoon baking powder 2 cups water 1 (14 ounce) can coconut milk 1 teaspoon vanilla extract ¼ teaspoon red food color ¼ cup potato starch, or as needed Directions Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch pan with cooking spray. Whisk mochiko, sugar, and baking powder together in a bowl. Combine water, coconut milk, vanilla, and food coloring in a medium bowl. Blend in dry ingredients, then pour into the prepared pan. Cover with foil. Bake in the preheated oven for 1 hour. Remove from the oven and let cool completely, 30 minutes to 1 hour. Dust a work surface with potato starch. Invert the pan onto the work surface. Use a plastic knife to cut into 36 squares. Recipe Tip The dango mochiko can be sticky to cut. They will stick less if you use a plastic knife. I Made It Print 194 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Chi Chi Dango 01 of 26 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 26 Photo by  allabouttreesnk 01/19/2022 Very good! Shared this recipe with my friends, they are excited to try it, too. Mahalo! 03 of 26 Photo by  Carrie Stagnaro 06/03/2020 04 of 26 Photo by  Fuza 04/13/2020 Made it in a water bath and it turned out perfectly. Will try with different flavours next. 05 of 26 Photo by  hnakl 10/26/2018 This recipe went very well! I added a pinch of salt, though. It was very sweet and it had a beautiful color! I used six drops of blue food coloring instead of red, actually. Looks really pretty and tastes delicious! I can’t wait to see what my friends think! 06 of 26 Photo by  hnakl 10/26/2018 This recipe went very well! I added a pinch of salt, though. It was very sweet and it had a beautiful color! I used six drops of blue food coloring instead of red, actually. Looks really pretty and tastes delicious! I can’t wait to see what my friends think! 07 of 26 Photo by  Wendy 07/30/2018 Awesome! 08 of 26 Photo by  Sofia Andaluz 10/10/2017 09 of 26 Photo by  Sofia Andaluz 10/10/2017 1 2 3 Next You’ll Also Love Microwave Chi Chi Dango Microwave Mochi 84 Ratings Pumpkin Mochi 95 Ratings Maja Blanca Maiz (Corn Pudding) 7 Ratings Japanese-Style Deep Fried Chicken 77 Ratings Butter Mochi Cake 21 Ratings Steamed Vegan Rice Cakes (Banh Bo Hap) 1 Rating Coconut Vanilla Doughnuts 1 Rating Purple Yam and Coconut Mochi (Ube Bibingka) 1 Rating Butter Mochi 30 Ratings Burmese Chicken-Coconut Soup (Ohn No Kyawswe) 20 Ratings Chewy Coconut Bibingka (Filipino Rice Cake) 7 Ratings Vegetarian Nori Rolls 23 Ratings Gluten-Free, Dairy-Free Coconut Brownies 18 Ratings Green Bean Curry 32 Ratings Homemade Sushi 216 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. instructions: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Blend in dry ingredients, then pour into the prepared pan. Cover with foil.;Bake in the preheated oven for 1 hour. Remove from the oven and let cool completely, 30 minutes to 1 hour.;Dust a work surface with potato starch. Invert the pan onto the work surface. Use a plastic knife to cut into 36 squares.
